awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: COVID Detection System Using a DNA Cage-Embedded Microfluidics Sensor
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a microfluidic sensor system has the potential to significantly impact public health efforts to control the spread of viruses. It can be used for rapid and reliable detection of viruses, including COVID-19, in home and point-of-care settings, enabling early diagnosis and treatment of infected individuals. This can help reduce the transmission of the virus and mitigate the overall impact of the pandemic. Successful commercialization of the technology will lead to significant market potential in disease surveillance and biomedical research. Ultimately, the project aims to play a critical role in mitigating the impact 
of COVID-19 and improving access to essential testing solutions for people worldwide. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a microfluidic system for detecting COVID-19. The gold electrode-covered microfluidic system is immobilized with DNA nanocages installed with aptamers or surface enzymes on the electrode surface that generates varying electrical impedance signals depending on the number of virus particles in a saliva sample injected into the system. The DNA origami nanocage technique, together with
aptamer/ACE2 enzymes are able to specifically capture the intact SARS-CoV-2 viruses. The immobilization of the DNA nanocage installed with aptamer/enzyme in a microfluidic system allows for easy, fast, and sensitive detection. The electrical impedance measurement provides an accurate label-free means of detecting the presence of the virus at nano-molar levels.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

A DNA-Based Sensor for Faster, Easier Virus Detection

A team of researchers and entrepreneurs from the University of Toledo is developing a groundbreaking device to detect viruses like COVID-19 quickly and painlessly. Their innovation combines advanced nanotechnology with user-friendly design, aiming to transform how we diagnose infectious diseases. Here’s what you need to know:

The Team Behind the Innovation
Leading the project are Dr. Yuan Tang and Dr. Dong-Shik Kim, professors with decades of experience in bioengineering and sensor technology. They’re joined by Khalid Khalaf and Hamidreza Ghaedamini, graduate students driving the project’s real-world testing, and Dr. James Huttner, a medical device inventor guiding the team’s business strategy. Together, they’ve trained through the National Science Foundation’s I-Corps program, a startup accelerator for scientists, to ensure their technology meets real-world needs.

How It Works
The device uses two key technologies: DNA origami and microfluidics. Imagine DNA origami as a tiny, programmable “cage” made of DNA strands. These cages are designed to trap viruses like COVID-19 by mimicking the shape of human cells that the virus naturally targets. Once a virus is captured, a microfluidic chip—a small, lab-on-a-chip device—detects the virus by measuring tiny electrical changes, delivering results in just 5–10 minutes via a smartphone app. Unlike nasal swabs, this test uses saliva or blood, making it less invasive.

Why It Matters
Current COVID-19 tests have drawbacks. PCR tests are accurate but slow (1–4 days for results) and require uncomfortable swabs. At-home kits are faster but less reliable. The Toledo team’s sensor aims to bridge this gap: it’s as accurate as PCR (97% sensitivity) but works in minutes, with no specialized equipment. Early lab tests are promising, and the team is refining the design to make it even more sensitive.

Listening to the Market
After interviewing over 100 doctors, patients, and industry experts, the team learned two critical lessons:

  1. Multiplexing is key: Hospitals want a single test to detect multiple viruses—like COVID-19, flu, and RSV—at once. This saves time and helps doctors make faster treatment decisions.

  2. Cost and convenience drive adoption: Patients dislike expensive, invasive tests. The team estimates their device will cost $50–$70 per use, competitive with existing options but with better performance.

Based on this feedback, the project shifted from focusing only on COVID-19 to creating a “multiplex” device that detects four viruses simultaneously. A prototype is expected by summer 2025.

Challenges and Solutions
The team is addressing hurdles identified at recent scientific conferences. For example, some virus-detection technologies use complex, expensive components like magnetic beads or antibodies. By contrast, the DNA origami approach simplifies the design, potentially lowering costs and improving reliability. The team is also exploring ways to ensure their sensor works consistently in real-world settings, like clinics or pharmacies.

Broader Impact
Beyond diagnostics, the project aims to inspire future scientists. The team integrates their research into university courses, giving students hands-on experience in cutting-edge tech like 3D printing and nanotechnology. They also host workshops for K–12 students, including programs to encourage girls to pursue engineering.

If successful, the sensor could democratize access to testing, especially in areas with limited healthcare. Faster, cheaper diagnoses could slow the spread of viruses and save lives during outbreaks.

What’s Next
The team is preparing to showcase their work at major trade shows and secure funding to scale production. They’re also refining the device to detect new virus variants and other diseases. With continued progress, this technology could reach hospitals, workplaces, and homes within a few years—turning complex science into a tool that protects everyday health.

In Summary
This project represents a fusion of biology, engineering, and entrepreneurship. By listening to patients and doctors, the team is creating a tool that’s not just innovative but truly practical—a reminder that the best solutions come from understanding the people who need them most.
